text:
Moving some of the discussion we've been having about the backend architecture here. So far we're thinking of breaking things down into the following components, although there could be something missing:
1. Fetching data from CommCare
2. Caching the data from CommCare (could be stored in a DB or something simpler)
3. Creating and serving the API for the visualization of that data

text:
It does look like the export tool supports automatic synchronization to a SQL database on a schedule. So maybe the following list of tasks makes more sense:

• Pick and set up a SQL database
• Set up commcare-export to download to the SQL database on a schedule
• Pick and set up backend framework that works with the SQL database
• Specify the API schema/endpoints format based on the database schema used by CommCare and frontend requirements
• Build the API based on the specification

elements.text: It does look like the export tool supports automatic synchronization to a SQL database on a schedule. So maybe the following list of tasks makes more sense:
Pick and set up a SQL database
Set up commcare-export to download to the SQL database on a schedule
Pick and set up backend framework that works with the SQL database
Specify the API schema/endpoints format based on the database schema used by CommCare and frontend requirements
Build the API based on the specification

text:
<@U0107A7161E> Sorry missed today's meeting, feel free to put my name under volunteers needed section item `#2`  <https://co.vid19.sg/dashboard|example 1> and <http://covid.fynsystems.com/|example 2> .

• BTW: who is the POC for <https://co.vid19.sg/dashboard|example 1>, not sure if there is a sample custom repo for `ET` under `Ethiopia-COVID19` GitHub repo ? 
• I've already started looking into <http://covid.fynsystems.com/|example 2>  and it looks promising `#Vue.js`, the FE can easily be integrate with any custom BE code base preferably Spring Boot + Spring Cloud + Spring Security OAuth (assuming most are familiar with Java makes it easy to find dev resources easily and quickly ! ) + Integrate the data points refenced <https://github.com/Ethiopia-COVID19/health-facilities-geojson>  
• Eventually wrap each modules within a docker/kubernetes container.

text:
Sounds good. I bet we can make a quick full circle.
1. Have the new  commcare form inputs as documented here by Samra <https://ethiopia-covid19.slack.com/archives/C010GQS9HNY/p1584859437008900>.
2. A small webhook service that listens for form entries and pushes data to a postgress db.
3. A graphql api that pulls the db data and provides clients to consume it.
4. The <https://github.com/Ethiopia-COVID19/Covid19.ET> can query the graphql and show the content in its dashboard.

attachments.text: Ethiopia - Covid19 live stats, case tracking and monitoring
attachments.title: Ethiopia-COVID19/Covid19.ET

elements.text:
Sounds good. I bet we can make a quick full circle.
1. Have the new  commcare form inputs as documented here by Samra

.
2. A small webhook service that listens for form entries and pushes data to a postgress db.
3. A graphql api that pulls the db data and provides clients to consume it.
4. The
can query the graphql and show the content in its dashboard.

text:
To summarize our direction so far:
	- we have decided to export the Commcare data to Postgres SQL (Commcare export tool supports directly exporting to it, and we have people comforable with it)
	- Gedion has tested the webhooks feature, and the plan is to insert the pushed-in JSON directly into the Postgres SQL (i.e. we probably will *not* do continuous polling using the comcare export tool)
	- We will provide an API for querying the database for visualization
		- we need to find out what JSI or other end consumers require from the API
		- FastAPI and Graphql have been suggested for building out the API

elements.text:
To summarize our direction so far:
	- we have decided to export the Commcare data to Postgres SQL (Commcare export tool supports directly exporting to it, and we have people comforable with it)
	- Gedion has tested the webhooks feature, and the plan is to insert the pushed-in JSON directly into the Postgres SQL (i.e. we probably will *not* do continuous polling using the comcare export tool)
	- We will provide an API for querying the database for visualization
		- we need to find out what JSI or other end consumers require from the API
		- FastAPI and Graphql have been suggested for building out the API

text:
<@U0107A7161E>
As you can see from this rather long thread, we are working towards a solution for storing the commcare data in a SQL database, and then provide an API to pull data out of it. If you can find any information on how JSI or other data consumers would like to to query the data out of the exported database (or if they would simply have direct access to the database) it would be helpful.

elements.text: As you can see from this rather long thread, we are working towards a solution for storing the commcare data in a SQL database, and then provide an API to pull data out of it. If you can find any information on how JSI or other data consumers would like to to query the data out of the exported database (or if they would simply have direct access to the database) it would be helpful.

attachments.text: አዲስ አበባ፣ መጋቢት 13፣ 2012 (ኤፍ.ቢ.ሲ) የኢንፎርሜሽን መረብ ደህንነት ኢጀንሲ (ኢመደኤ)“የኢትዮጵያ የተቀናጀ የኮሮና ቫይረስ (ኮቪድ19) መከታተያና መቆጣጠሪያ ሲስትም” አዘጋጀ። አዲስ የተዘጋጀው ሲስተም ኢትዮጵያ የኮሮና ቫይረስ (ኮቪድ19) ሥርጭትን ለመግታት የምታደርገውን ጊዜ የማይሰጥ ርብርብ የሚያግዝ መሆኑንም የኢንፎርሜሽን መረብ ደህንነት ኤጀንሲ (ኢመደኤ) ባወጣው መረጃ አስታውቋል። የተዘጋጀው ሲስተም የተለያዩ መረጃዎችን የሚሰጥ መሆኑን  ያስታወቀው ኤጀንሲው፤ ከእነዚህ መካከልም፦ ሀገራዊ፣ አህጉራዊ እና …

text: Hey everyone, regarding how we can use the data to help the MoH make more informed decisions, I think a good starting point is helping them identify which hospitals will be at capacity and when. Looking at the site <@U010FJJH4DC> shared, showing the spread of infection, I think this can be applied, with the location of all the health facilities and reported cases, to show that. I've contacted the person who created the calculator to better understand how we can build our own model. We could use that to connect to the MoH database and give them live reporting on the spread and the list of locations at risk of becoming over capacity.

elements.text: Hey everyone, regarding how we can use the data to help the MoH make more informed decisions, I think a good starting point is helping them identify which hospitals will be at capacity and when. Looking at the site

shared, showing the spread of infection, I think this can be applied, with the location of all the health facilities and reported cases, to show that. I've contacted the person who created the calculator to better understand how we can build our own model. We could use that to connect to the MoH database and give them live reporting on the spread and the list of locations at risk of becoming over capacity.

text: As discussed yesterday, I'd like to continue working on creating a webhook that forwards commcare data to our desired databases. The commcare forwarding page has a monitoring tool that keeps track of what has been sent, what has not and allows for retries. This gives us a simple integration to pull the data in realtime from commcare. If someone can jump on setting up the postgres db, I can work on the webhook that pushes the data.

elements.text: As discussed yesterday, I'd like to continue working on creating a webhook that forwards commcare data to our desired databases. This gives us a simple integration to pull the data in realtime from commcare. If someone can jump on setting up the postgres db, I can work on the webhook that pushes the data.

text: <@U0105UGHFUK> has joined the channel
<@U010HDMR4H3> has joined the channel

Just a note: In addition to the ongoing efforts: there are a lot to be done to deal with such as an outbreak, generally: surveillance, testing, management, (and cure). By _surveilling_, it means tools and techniques for predicting or providing early warnings of outbreak of novel or known pathogens. By _testing it_ means diagnosing individual patients with the disease. By _managing_, it means the tools and techniques for better understanding and limiting the spread of the outbreak, providing care, and engaging the citizenry. [[By _curing_, it means the development of therapeutic agents to administer to infected individuals. In all of these areas, the lone data scientist working without true problem understanding can be misguided at best and detrimental at worst.]]

elements.text: Just a note: In addition to the ongoing efforts: there are a lot to be done to deal with such as an outbreak, generally: surveillance, testing, management, (and cure). By
surveilling

testing it
means diagnosing individual patients with the disease. By
managing

curing

, it means the development of therapeutic agents to administer to infected individuals. In all of these areas, the lone data scientist working without true problem understanding can be misguided at best and detrimental at worst.]]

text: <@U0100B5MHDG>

<@U01084M48U8> I agree, and would appreciate any input you have in regards to projects to work on. This is also why we would need input from health officials and epidemiologists to fill in the domain expertise we lack.

elements.text: I agree, and would appreciate any input you have in regards to projects to work on. This is also why we would need input from health officials and epidemiologists to fill in the domain expertise we lack.

text: <@U0100B5MHDG> the domain experts are key here.  Otherwise, it won't serve the purpose.

elements.text: the domain experts are key here.  Otherwise, it won't serve the purpose.

elements.text: to this spreadsheet?

text: In the pathogen prediction, there are a large number of known pathogens, but for most of them, it is not known whether they can transfer from animals into humans (and develop into outbreaks). It may be possible to predict the likely candidates by training on features of known pathogens.  For example on this paper describe some techniques were described <http://www.dssgfellowship.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/necamp.pdf>, in partnership with disease ecologist who defined the relevant features, but didn’t get very far because the features of pathogens are not available in a nice clean tabular dataset; they are locked up inside scientific publications. Knowledge extraction from these very specialized documents automatically requires a lot of expert ecologist-annotated documents, which is not tenable. Even if we were able to pull together a dataset suitable for predicted cases, it is difficult to know how to make heads or tails of the results without the disease ecologists.

elements.text: In the pathogen prediction, there are a large number of known pathogens, but for most of them, it is not known whether they can transfer from animals into humans (and develop into outbreaks). It may be possible to predict the likely candidates by training on features of known pathogens.  For example on this paper describe some techniques were described

, in partnership with disease ecologist who defined the relevant features, but didn’t get very far because the features of pathogens are not available in a nice clean tabular dataset; they are locked up inside scientific publications. Knowledge extraction from these very specialized documents automatically requires a lot of expert ecologist-annotated documents, which is not tenable. Even if we were able to pull together a dataset suitable for predicted cases, it is difficult to know how to make heads or tails of the results without the disease ecologists.

text: Just to clarify in this specific working group (Surveillance response) I don't think we are doing such things, rather we focus on data collection at the point of entry (boarder, e.g., airport), house to house surveillance data collection (case by case), and targeted locations (e.g., shopping centers, taxi/bus services, etc). I am really thinking here if we just develop an easy ML/CNN models and deploy put on mobile phones to be used any point of public contact.  I will be listing what potential data sources we can collect - remember, we are talking about Ethiopia and most the data collection technologies may not work and we need to be frugal and agile.

elements.text: Just to clarify in this specific working group (Surveillance response) I don't think we are doing such things, rather we focus on data collection at the point of entry (boarder, e.g., airport), house to house surveillance data collection (case by case), and targeted locations (e.g., shopping centers, taxi/bus services, etc). I am really thinking here if we just develop an easy ML/CNN models and deploy put on mobile phones to be used any point of public contact.  I will be listing what potential data sources we can collect - remember, we are talking about Ethiopia and most the data collection technologies may not work and we need to be frugal and agile.

text: Do you think there would be enough data to output reliably accurate results, especially early on when there aren't as many reported cases?

elements.text: Do you think there would be enough data to output reliably accurate results, especially early on when there aren't as many reported cases?

text: Another concern I have is using ML when there are other methods epidemiologists use to model the spread. Perhaps with a large enough dataset an ML model would perform better, but maybe we should try starting with seeing what an epidemiologist would apply. What do you think <@U01084M48U8>?

elements.text: Another concern I have is using ML when there are other methods epidemiologists use to model the spread. Perhaps with a large enough dataset an ML model would perform better, but maybe we should try starting with seeing what an epidemiologist would apply. What do you think

text: yes

elements.text: yes

text: The data issue is the problem. We don't have enough sample - we may go with some uncertainty and error correction. but I my several experiences that won't be acceptable for decision making by domain experts.

elements.text: The data issue is the problem. We don't have enough sample - we may go with some uncertainty and error correction. but I my several experiences that won't be acceptable for decision making by domain experts.

text: Yes epidemiologists use mechanistic models - there are several ongoing works that combines these models with ML/AI approaches. Happy to share some.

elements.text: Yes epidemiologists use mechanistic models - there are several ongoing works that combines these models with ML/AI approaches. Happy to share some.

text: That would be great if you could share them with the channel!

elements.text: That would be great if you could share them with the channel!

text: <@U01084M48U8>/<@U0100B5MHDG> I would like to be part if this effort as well. Generally, I think statistical methods would be better suited than - ML mainly because of the the size of the data. Regardless, I would like to collaborate and come up with a meaningful solution.

elements.text: I would like to be part if this effort as well. Generally, I think statistical methods would be better suited than - ML mainly because of the the size of the data. Regardless, I would like to collaborate and come up with a meaningful solution.

text: As you know, the best thing to do is the `Outbreak early warning`. The earlier we know that an outbreak is starting, the earlier actions can be taken to contain it. There are often small signals in various reports and other data that indicate a disaster is beginning.

elements.text: As you know, the best thing to do is the
Outbreak early warning

. The earlier we know that an outbreak is starting, the earlier actions can be taken to contain it. There are often small signals in various reports and other data that indicate a disaster is beginning.

text: I agree <@U0100B5MHDG> stat methods are the first class. I want to have a call with a small group of us (must include domain experts on the ground) to discuss on 1: Data, 2) Approaches; 3) existing platforms (possibly open source) we can tap; 4) Key capabilities to quickly build out.

elements.text: I agree

stat methods are the first class. I want to have a call with a small group of us (must include domain experts on the ground) to discuss on 1: Data, 2) Approaches; 3) existing platforms (possibly open source) we can tap; 4) Key capabilities to quickly build out.

text:
<@U0100B5MHDG> et el . here are some of available cover-19 models

1. <https://www.medrxiv.org/content/10.1101/2020.02.12.20022566v1.full.pdf>
_implemented in C and is available on github (<http://github.com/ldanon/MetaWards>). The data are freely available from the Office for National Statistics website, or can be downloaded with the code at the github repository._ 

2. <https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2762510>
_The data surrounding the biology, epidemiology, and clinical characteristics of the SARS-CoV-2 virus have been growing daily, with more than 400 articles listed in PubMed. The virus genome was rapidly sequenced, which allowed the development of diagnostic tests and for research into vaccine and therapeutics to start. Meanwhile, the clinical spectrum of disease continues to be defined (including the potential for asymptomatic spread) and clinical trials evaluating treatments have begun._

3. <https://twitter.com/trvrb/status/1239427193945485312>
4. <https://medium.com/@tomaspueyo/coronavirus-the-hammer-and-the-dance-be9337092b56>
Strong coronavirus measures today should only last a few weeks, there shouldn’t be a big peak of infections afterwards, and it can all be done for a reasonable cost to society, saving millions of lives along the way. If we don’t take these measures, tens of millions will be infected, many will die, along with anybody else that requires intensive care, because the healthcare system will have collapsed.
<https://github.com/topics/covid-19>

<https://cmmid.github.io/topics/covid19/control-measures/>
 Control measures  
This page list all our work on control measures for Covid-19. The list below shows all our work on this topic

<https://www.ft.com/content/0dba7ea8-6713-11ea-800d-da70cff6e4d3>

<https://www.who.int/bulletin/online_first/20-253591.pdf>
Variant analysis of COVID-19 genomes 
T. Koyama, D. Platt & L. Parida

<http://rocs.hu-berlin.de/corona/>
<https://www.vox.com/2020/2/20/21143785/coronavirus-covid-19-spread-transmission-how>
• What does this imply about the contagiousness of Covid-19 and stopping the outbreak? “For a virus pretty closely related to SARS, it shows very effective person-to-person transmission, something nobody really expected,” Stephen Morse, a professor of epidemiology at Columbia University Mailman School of Public Health, told Vox. 
• Researchers currently believe one <https://www.vox.com/2020/2/18/21142009/coronavirus-covid19-china-wuhan-deaths-pandemic|infected person generally infects two to more than three others>, which would make the new coronavirus more contagious than seasonal flu, SARS and MERS.
<https://www.medrxiv.org/content/10.1101/2020.02.10.20021725v1.full.pdf>
Beyond R0: the importance of contact tracing when predicting epidemics

<https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/2002/2002.07112.pdf>
We forecasted curves of cumulative confirmed cases of Covid-19 across China from Jan 20, 2020 to April20, 2020. Using the multiple-step forecasting, the estimated average errors of 6-step, 7-step, 8-step, 9-step and 10-step forecasting were 1.64%, 2.27%, 2.14%, 2.08%, 0.73%, respectively. We predicted that the time points of the provinces/cities entering the plateau of the forecasted transmission dynamic curves varied, ranging from Jan 21 to April19, 2020. The34 provinces/cities were grouped into 9 clusters.

elements.text: et el . here are some of available cover-19 models
implemented in C and is available on github (
). The data are freely available from the Office for National Statistics website, or can be downloaded with the code at the github repository.

The data surrounding the biology, epidemiology, and clinical characteristics of the SARS-CoV-2 virus have been growing daily, with more than 400 articles listed in PubMed. The virus genome was rapidly sequenced, which allowed the development of diagnostic tests and for research into vaccine and therapeutics to start. Meanwhile, the clinical spectrum of disease continues to be defined (including the potential for asymptomatic spread) and clinical trials evaluating treatments have begun.

Strong coronavirus measures today should only last a few weeks, there shouldn’t be a big peak of infections afterwards, and it can all be done for a reasonable cost to society, saving millions of lives along the way. If we don’t take these measures, tens of millions will be infected, many will die, along with anybody else that requires intensive care, because the healthcare system will have collapsed.

Control measures  
This page list all our work on control measures for Covid-19. The list below shows all our work on this topic

Variant analysis of COVID-19 genomes 
T. Koyama, D. Platt & L. Parida

What does this imply about the contagiousness of Covid-19 and stopping the outbreak? “For a virus pretty closely related to SARS, it shows very effective person-to-person transmission, something nobody really expected,” Stephen Morse, a professor of epidemiology at Columbia University Mailman School of Public Health, told Vox.
Researchers currently believe one
infected person generally infects two to more than three others
, which would make the new coronavirus more contagious than seasonal flu, SARS and MERS.
Beyond R0: the importance of contact tracing when predicting epidemics

We forecasted curves of cumulative confirmed cases of Covid-19 across China from Jan 20, 2020 to April20, 2020. Using the multiple-step forecasting, the estimated average errors of 6-step, 7-step, 8-step, 9-step and 10-step forecasting were 1.64%, 2.27%, 2.14%, 2.08%, 0.73%, respectively. We predicted that the time points of the provinces/cities entering the plateau of the forecasted transmission dynamic curves varied, ranging from Jan 21 to April19, 2020. The34 provinces/cities were grouped into 9 clusters.
